items.title: In Rural Minnesota, a 70-Acre Lab for Sustainable Living
items.abstract: Imagine a house that can go without heating for two days in a bitterly cold winter. Or a greenhouse with what may be the largest hot-air solar panel array in North America.

items.title: Rendering a City With a Blowtorch
items.abstract: Belarus Free Theater offers a scathing mosaic of its home city with “Minsk, 2011,” at the Under the Radar festival at the Public Theater.

items.title: A City Drenched in Sugar
items.abstract: New Orleans, where bakery loyalties run deep, has become a laboratory for desserts — especially when it comes to the popular king cake and its many variations.

items.title: Patent Producers Clustered in Only a Few Cities
items.abstract: A new study by the Brookings Institution shows the high concentration of patented innovation in a relatively small number of metropolitan areas in America. Twenty metro areas — home to 34 percent of the population — generate 63 percent of the nation’s patents.

items.title: Warming Effect of Urban Activities Felt Widely
items.abstract: Scientists studying weather and energy consumption have found that activities from urban areas can warm the air by nearly 2 degrees as far as 1,000 miles away.

items.title: Pritzker Prize for Architecture Is Awarded to Alejandro Aravena of Chile
items.abstract: Mr. Aravena, who has focused on low-cost social housing and reconstructing after natural disasters, received the honor as Chile emerges as a locus of noteworthy architecture.

items.title: New York City Is Set to Adopt New Approach on Policing Minor Offenses
items.abstract: The measures would affect low-level offenses such as littering, public urination and public consumption of alcohol, in some cases removing them from the criminal justice system.

items.title: New York City Can Require Sodium Warnings, Judge Rules
items.abstract: The National Restaurant Association had sought to halt a measure requiring chain restaurants to warn customers about high salt levels in menu items.

items.title: Challenging Washington’s Architectural History
items.abstract: Architectural diversity on Washington's National Mall is in full flower.

items.title: Lead Problems Elsewhere Prompt New York Schools to Show Drinking Water Is Safe
items.abstract: The Education Department was sending letters home with students that include an address for a website where parents can track the results of lead testing in schools.

items.title: The End Is Nigh. Can Design Save Us?
items.abstract: The Milan Triennial showcases projects by designers, architects and artists that highlight humanity’s troubled relationship to nature.

items.title: Big Buildings Hurt the Climate. New York City Hopes to Change That.
items.abstract: To fight climate change, the city is forcing the buildings, like the Empire State Building and Trump Tower, to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

items.title: New York Bans Alcohol Ads on Most City Property
items.abstract: Citing the health risk to young people and vulnerable populations, the city announced the ban that could lead to a loss of $3 million in yearly advertising fees.

items.title: Celebrating ‘Good Design’ at MoMA: The Nut Dish and Other Populist Gems
items.abstract: “If most Americans had little patience for Picasso, everybody needed a decent can opener,” our critic writes.

items.title: How New York City Is Turning Its Thousands of Roofs Into Power Providers
items.abstract: Manhattan now has the country’s biggest array of solar panels on an apartment complex. The Bronx could soon have a bigger one.

items.title: Cannabis Events Come Out of Hiding in New York City
items.abstract: As New Yorkers wait for marijuana sales to be legalized, some small businesses are putting down roots.

items.title: India’s budget focuses on roads, but critics see need for more jobs.
items.abstract: Narendra Modi’s plan calls for a big increase in infrastructure spending. Some say more must be done to create jobs for the country’s young work force.

items.title: Russia Fires Missile Barrage at Ukrainian Cities and Military Targets
items.abstract: The strikes seemed aimed at hampering Ukraine’s war fighting capacity as the conflict shifts to eastern Donbas region, and at responding to the sinking of a Russian warship.

items.title: City Living, With Less Water
items.abstract: Los Angeles and Santiago are two of the latest cities to impose strict water restrictions in an effort to avoid disastrous shortages in the future.
keywords: Metropolitan Water District of Southern California

items.title: New York City’s fifth wave
items.abstract: The latest wave is being driven by Omicron subvariants.
